case_name: Sardar Gian Singh v. Financial Commissioner, Punjab

facts.text: Sardar Gian Singh was recruited in 1927 as a Naib Tehsildar in the Revenue department of the Province of Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: Sardar Gian Singh - hereinafter Called the appellant - was recruited in 1927 as a Naib Tehsildar in the Revenue department of the Province of Punjab.

facts.text: Appellant was confirmed in the rank of Naib Tehsildar in 1939.

anchor.surface_text: He was companyfirmed in that rank in 1939.

facts.text: Appellant was promoted to officiating Tehsildar in 1946.

anchor.surface_text: In 1946, he was promoted to the rank of officiating Tehsildar and was posted as Tehsildar at Hansi in the district of Hissar on September 22, 1947,

facts.text: Appellant posted as Tehsildar at Hansi on September 22, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: and was posted as Tehsildar at Hansi in the district of Hissar on September 22, 1947, and since then he held the post of Tehsildar at diverse places.

facts.text: Appellant served with charge sheet containing eleven heads of charges of misappropriation, misconduct, irregularities and dereliction of duties on August 20, 1952 by Financial Commissioner, Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: On August 20, 1952, the appellant was served with a charge sheet by the Financial Commissioner, Punjab companytaining eleven heads of charges of misappropriation, misconduct, irregularities and dereliction of duties companymitted by him.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner, Hissar appointed to hold departmental enquiry into the charges.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Commissioner. Hissar was appointed to hold a departmental enquiry into those charges.

facts.text: Appellant served with notice to show cause on August 28, 1953 why he should not be dismissed based on enquiry findings.

anchor.surface_text: On August 28, 1953, the appellant was served with a numberice to show cause why on the findings recorded by the enquiry officer, he should number be dismissed from service.

facts.text: Appellant submitted explanation to show cause notice.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant submitted his explanation.

facts.text: Financial Commissioner ordered dismissal of appellant from service on October 26, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The Financial Commissioner by order dated October 26, 1953 ordered that the appellant be dismissed from service.

facts.text: Appeal against dismissal order was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal preferred against that order was dismissed and application to the Government of Punjab to revise the order of the appellate authority also proved infructuous.

facts.text: Revision application to Government of Punjab dismissed as infructuous.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal preferred against that order was dismissed and application to the Government of Punjab to revise the order of the appellate authority also proved infructuous.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition under Article 226 of Constitution in High Court of Punjab seeking quashing of dismissal order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then presented a petition under Article 226 of the Constitution to the High Court of Punjab for an order quashing the order of dismissal companytending inter alia that

facts.text: Petitioner claimed no reasonable opportunity given to rebut allegations before enquiry officer or Financial Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: a reasonable opportunity was number given to the appellant either before the enquiry officer or before the Financial Commissioner to rebut the allegations companytained in the charge sheet,

facts.text: Petitioner claimed Financial Commissioner incompetent to pass dismissal order.

anchor.surface_text: b that the Financial Commissioner was incompetent to pass the order of dismissal.

facts.text: Bishan Narain J rejected plea of no reasonable opportunity but held Financial Commissioner lacked power to dismiss due to amendment of Punjab Land Revenue Act by Adaptation Order 1937.

anchor.surface_text: Bishan Narain, J., who heard the petition rejected the first plea, but in the view of the learned Judge, the Financial Commissioner ceased to have any power to make rules regulating the appointment and dismissal of Tehsildars because of the amendment of the Punjab Land Revenue Act, 1887 by the Government of India Adaptation of Indian Laws Order, 1937

facts.text: Division Bench of High Court reversed single judge order, held Tehsildari Rules continued by virtue of clauses 9 and 10 of Adaptation Order 1937, Financial Commissioner had power to dismiss.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal under clause 10 of the Letters Patent, a Division Bench of the High Court reversed the order passed by the Bishan Narain, J. The High Court held that by virtue of clauses 9 and 10 of the Government of India Adaptation of Indian Laws Order, 1937, the rules framed under the Punjab Land Revenue Act, 1887 companytinued to remain in operation even after the Act was amended by the Adaptation of Indian Laws Order, 1937 and the Financial Commissioner remained invested with the power to dismiss the appellant from service.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Supreme Court with certificate of fitness under Article 133.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has appealed to this Court against the order of the High Court with certificates of fitness under Article 133 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Rules for appointment and dismissal of Tehsildars framed in 1932 by Financial Commissioner under section 9 read with section 28 of Punjab Land Revenue Act, 1887.

anchor.surface_text: Under section 9 read with section 28 of the Act, rules were framed in 1932 by the Financial Commissioner Punjab, and authority to appointed Tehsildars and to remove them from service was, by these rules, companyferred upon the Financial Commissioner.

facts.text: Section 9 of Punjab Land Revenue Act amended by Adaptation of Indian Laws Order, 1937 deleting power of Financial Commissioner to make rules for appointment and dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: After the enactment of the Government of India Act, 1935, section 9 of the Punjab Land Revenue Act was amended by the Adaptation of Indian Laws Order, 1937, and the power of the Financial Commissioner to make rules under section 9 was abrogated by the deletion of the words in that section following the word appointed.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Financial Commissioner had power to dismiss appellant as Tehsildari Rules continued in force.

anchor.surface_text: the order of the Financial Commissioner dismissing the appellant from service was number unauthorised.

arguments.claim: The Tehsildari Rules framed in 1932 under section 9 read with section 28 of the Punjab Land Revenue Act conferred authority on the Financial Commissioner to appoint and remove Tehsildars

anchor.surface_text: Under section 9 read with section 28 of the Act, rules were framed in 1932 by the Financial Commissioner Punjab, and authority to appointed Tehsildars and to remove them from service was, by these rules, conferred upon the Financial Commissioner.

arguments.claim: Amendment of section 9 by Adaptation of Indian Laws Order, 1937 abrogated the power of the Financial Commissioner to make rules but existing rules continued by clause 9 which provides that adaptations shall not render prior rules invalid

anchor.surface_text: Again, the Adaptation of Indian Laws Order, 1937 expressly provided by clause 9 that the rules framed under the Act - adapted or modified - shall not be rendered invalid. By that clause which provided The provisions of this order which adapt or modify Indian laws so as to alter the manner in which, the authority by which, or the law under or in accordance with which, any powers are exercisable, shall not render invalid any notification, order, commitment, attachment, bye-law, rule or regulation duly made or issued

arguments.claim: By clause 10 of Adaptation Order, powers vested before commencement of Part III of GOI Act 1935 continue until other provision made

anchor.surface_text: And by clause 10 which provided Save as provided by this order, all powers which under any law in force in British India, or in any part of British India, were immediately before the commencement of part III of the Government of India Act, 1935 vested in, or exercisable by, any person or authority shall continue to be so vested or exercisable until other provision is made by some legislature or authority empowered to regulate the matter in question.

holdings.text: the order of the Financial Commissioner dismissing the appellant from service was not unauthorised

anchor.surface_text: the order of the Financial Commissioner dismissing the appellant from service was number unauthorised.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tehsildari Rules continued in force by clause 9 of Adaptation Order saving prior rules from invalidity and clause 10 continuing pre-existing powers; conditions of service unaltered by transitory provisions until new rules made.

holdings.text: Notwithstanding the abrogation of the powers of the Financial Commissioner to frame rules, the Tehsildari Rules, 1932 remained in force

anchor.surface_text: Notwithstanding the abrogation of the powers of the Financial Commissioner to frame rules, the Tehsildari Rules, 1932 remained in force. And by clause 10 which provided Save as provided by this order

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clause 9 expressly saves rules, notifications etc. made before adaptation from being rendered invalid; clause 10 saves vesting of powers until other provision made.

holdings.text: Clause 7 of the Adaptation of Indian Laws Order [...] does not also assist the appellant
holdings.reasoning_summary: Clause 7 applies only where old authority ceased to exist and corresponding new authority constituted under GOI Act; here Financial Commissioner continued to exist, powers merely vested elsewhere in some cases.

holdings.text: the Civil Services Rules were not to apply to any person for whose appointments and conditions of service special provision was made by or under any law for the time being in force
holdings.reasoning_summary: Tehsildari Rules provided special provision for appointment and conditions of Tehsildars; no evidence they were superseded; plea not raised in High Court and notifications not produced.

holdings.text: Section 16(1) General Clauses Act, clearly provides that the power of appointment includes the power to suspend or dismiss
holdings.reasoning_summary: General Clauses Act s.16(1) statutorily includes dismissal power in appointment power; vesting of appointment carries dismissal authority.

holdings.text: the record does not support the contention that the Punjab Tehsildari Rules were not in operation at the date of dismissal
holdings.reasoning_summary: No notifications produced showing supersession; plea not advanced in High Court; difficult to entertain new plea requiring external evidence.

anchor.surface_text: This is number really disputed and has the support of the observations in Watson v. Winch   1916  1 K. B. 688 . The Revenue Act, after amendment, did number provide about the appointment of Tehsildars and Naib Tehsildars. This must have been in view of the statutory provision existing for the purpose in sub-section 1 of section 241 of the Act whose relevant portion is Except as expressly provided by this Act, appointments to the civil services of, and civil posts under, the Crown is India, shall, after the companymencement of Part III of this Act, be made - x x x x x x  b  in the case of services of province, and posts in companynection with the affairs of a province, by the Governor or such person as he may direct.

precedents.cited_proposition: consequence of repeal of a power is that the power is deemed never to have existed and rules framed under it are without jurisdiction

precedents.citation: Pradyat Kumar v. Chief Justice of Calcutta

anchor.surface_text: In Pradyat Kumar v. Chief Justice of Calcutta this Court had to companysider whether the Chief Justice of the Calcutta High Court had power to dismiss an employee of the High Court. In this companynection, it was number disputed that the Chief Justice was the authority for appointing the appellant. But it was companytended that he had number the power to dismiss. The companytention was that the appellant was a public servant governed by the Civil Services  Classification, Control and Appeal  Rules of 1930, as amended from time to time and that those rules companytinued to apply even after the Government of India Act, 1935, and later when the Constitution of India came into force. It was number disputed that dismissal was a matter falling within companydition of service of a public servant as held by the Privy Council in North West Frontier Province v. Suraj Narain Anand , and that the power of making rules relating to the companyditions of service of staff of High Court was vested in the Chief Justice of the High Court under section 242 4  taken with section 241 of the Act and also under Article 229 2 , of the companystitution.

precedents.case_name: Pradyat Kumar v Chief Justice of Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: power of appointment carries with it the power of dismissal
precedents.cited_holding: power of appointment was throughout understood as vesting ... the complete administrative and disciplinary control over its staff, including the power of dismissal

precedents.citation: North West Frontier Province v. Suraj Narain Anand

anchor.surface_text: It was number disputed that dismissal was a matter falling within companydition of service of a public servant as held by the Privy Council in North West Frontier Province v. Suraj Narain Anand , and that the power of making rules relating to the companyditions of service of staff of High Court was vested in the Chief Justice of the High Court under section 242 4  taken with section 241 of the Act and also under Article 229 2 , of the companystitution. It was however companytended that the Chief Justice of the High Court had number framed any such rules and that therefore, by virtue of section 276 of the Act and Article 313 of the companystitution, the Civil Services Rules companytinued to apply to the appellant.

precedents.case_name: North West Frontier Province v Suraj Narain Anand
precedents.cited_proposition: dismissal is a matter falling within condition of service of a public servant

precedents.citation: Pradyat Kumar v. Chief Justice of Calcutta

anchor.surface_text: In this companynection I may quote the very apposite observations in Pradyat Kumar v. Chief Justice of Calcutta The companytinued application of the Civil Services Rules without such adaptation would result in the anomalous position, that although the 1935 Act specifically vests in the Chief Justice the power of appointment and of framing rules regulating companyditions of service including the power of dismissal and hence thereby indicates the Chief Justice as the authority having the power to exercise disciplinary companytrol, he has numbersuch disciplinary companytrol merely because he did number choose to make any fresh rules and was companytent with the companytinued application of the old rules.

precedents.case_name: Pradyat Kumar v Chief Justice of Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: continued application of old rules without adaptation leads to anomalous position where new vesting of power is undermined
precedents.cited_holding: The continued application of the Civil Services Rules without such adaptation would result in the anomalous position, that although the 1935 Act specifically vests in the Chief Justice the power of appointment and of framing rules regulating conditions of service including the power of dismissal ... he has no such disciplinary control merely because he did not choose to make any fresh rules
